title: Ticket #990: Address new ClassAds performance concerns
description:
Summary of new ClassAds Optimization Task

This is one of the identified flightworthy development activities for 7.5.

Current people assigned to work on this: Jim Hill and Dan Bradley

As shown in #227, new classads performs about 5x slower matchmaking and 1-2x slower in instantiating real job and machine ads. Our job is to figure out why and if possible fix it.

Tasks and Due Dates

  1. 2009-12-4 [DONE]: Profile the benchmarks and understand where the CPU time is being spent.

  2. 2009-12-18 [DONE]: Optimize algorithms identified as problematic.

  3. 2010-01-08: (Jim) Add tests of FlattenAndInline to classad_functional_tester.

  4. Once integration of new classads into Condor is done, run performance tests of full Condor system (e.g. submit 100k jobs, drain 100k queue) and see if there are any performance issues relating to the new classad integration.

  5. Optimize again if needed.

Matchmaking Optimizations

How much slower new ClassAds is than old ClassAds is reported here for each optimization. The comparison was done using the loop times for cabench_query-newlist. How much difference each optimization makes depends on the order in which they are applied in some cases. I'm just reporting what I observed when applying optimizations in the following order:

  1. 4.8x: no optimization

  2. 3.9x: using hash_map for AttrList

  3. 1.8x: compiling with -O2 (1.7x for -O3, which doesn't seem worth it). It is interesting to note that old classads is not helped much by compiler optimization. I think it is the STL code in new classads that benefits so much from optimization.

  4. 1.4x: using max depth instead of EvalState cache.

  5. 0.72x: FlattenAndInline machine requirements before matchmaking. Without special attention to references to "MY" this was 0.84x in my tests.

  6. 0.62x: Optimize structure of the match ad and flatten references to TARGET to a single global-scope lookup.

  7. 0.39x: Add short-circuiting in && and || operators.

Conclusion: It seems a good idea to "flatten" the requirements expressions before matchmaking, since they will usually be evaluated multiple times. This, in combination with the other optimizations allows us to do matchmaking at a faster rate than with old ClassAds.

TODO: I noticed that flattening does not simplify some expressions such as (true && X --> X where X is some boolean expression). It may be worth making it smarter. Ideally, the flattening would happen before the ads are sent to the collector, saving a little cpu time in the central manager. However, it doesn't appear to make a big difference. Inlining might bloat memory usage a bit (6% in our test), but further simplification could help counter that. To reduce memory usage, it might be worth flattening (but not inlining) all attributes other than requirements.

Parser Optimizations

How much slower new ClassAds is than old ClassAds is reported here for each optimization. The comparison was done using the setup time for cabench_query-newlist. How much difference each optimization makes depends on the order in which they are applied in some cases. I'm just reporting what I observed when applying optimizations in the following order:

  1. 1.7x: no optimizations

  2. 1.4x: optimize ClassAd::Insert() to use single-lookup insertion method.

  3. 1.5x: using hash_map for AttrList.

  4. 0.85x: compiling with -O2

  5. 0.89x: FlattenAndInline machine requirements before matchmaking. Inlining caused 6% increase in memory usage.

Conclusion: the optimizations we did to improve matchmaking did not hurt parsing speed. Individually, some of them slow down parsing slightly, but overall parsing is faster.
remarks:
2009-Dec-02 17:26:40 by danb:

Observations

We looked at the following using callgrind: 

  cabench_query-newlist --enable-2way 3 collector.ads-new 10000 '[Requirements = (target.Arch == "X86_64"); JobUniverse = 5; MyType = "Job"; TargetType = "Machine"]'

looking up attributes

Matchmaking in new ClassAds spends about 30% of its time looking up attributes in ClassAds.

In the 1.2 million calls to ClassAd::Lookup(), there are 6.4 million calls to strcasecmp(). The AttrList data structure is an stl map, which is implemented as a balanced tree, so I would expect O(log(N)) string comparisons per lookup. The machine ads in this sample have ~160 attributes, and log2(160)=7.3, which is close to the observed ratio of 5.3 string compares/lookup calls.

Question: would it be better to use a hash table here? Old classads uses a hash table. Matchmaking with new ClassAds is about 4.5x slower than old. In new ClassAds we observe 5x as many string compares as lookups in this benchmark. Since we only spend 30% of our time in lookups, I'm being sloppy to suggest that the 4.5x slowdown is due to the 5x string compares, but it is still a tempting comparison to make.

Also: in some simple tests I did, strcasecmp() is ~60 times more expensive than strcmp(). If we could figure out how to canonicalize strings without hurting memory size too much, this could be a big win.

state cache

In AttributeReference::_Evaluate(), there is some stuff that looks things up and adds things to state.cache. This consumes ~30% of the matchmaking time. The intention is to prevent infinite recursion due to recursive references and to speed up evaluation when there are multiple references to the same thing. I suspect that the overhead of copying evaluation results into the cache is greater than the typical savings from reusing those results. If we get rid of the cache, we would just need some way of preventing infinite recursion. This could be done with a simple depth counter and a fixed maximum depth, or it could be done with something like the existing solution (using a set or hash data structure) but without the overhead of caching the evaluated results.

insertion into map/hash

The existing pattern for inserting attributes into ClassAds and the eval state cache is to first search for an existing entry using find(), remove it if there is one, and then insert. It should be more efficient to attempt to insert and if this fails due to an existing entry to modify the entry returned by insert() (i.e. only one lookup in all cases).

2009-Dec-10 17:37:42 by danb:
I just found a big memory leak in the Flatten() code. This makes me less confident that this code has been rigorously tested. If we are to trust it, I think we need to create a suite of tests that check the validity of the flattened expressions.
